nodes.bodyText: Curious: are the default implementation there for backwards compatibility?
Yeah, for all newly introduced methods :)
Nit: I think renaming typeHandlers to handlersPerType is slightly clearer. Might be a taste thing though, hence marked as a nit.

Isn't it smarter to perform this check on line 183, thus prior to entering the for-loop of the typeHandlers.getValue()? Or, does the typeHandlers.getKey() outcome differ per handler you're dealing with?
Of course it is :) Thanks for noticing.
Is this TODO still present in subsequent commits? If so, think it would be best to resolve this prior to merging.
I left it here more like an open question. Your opinion is much appreciated.
So your to do could be summarized as should we have a MessageHandlingMember#getDeclaringClass, correct?
yes, was thinking whether we want to do it or not.
Just to clarify this method a bit more, a slight portion of javadoc would be helpful I think.
More for maintenance then for framework users of course.
I'll do it!
Why provide the entire target if you're only using the target its class?
No reason, you're right.

Had to check the interface to make this clearer to me. What would help to point out that this method is about creating models for an aggregate's entity, is to change the parameter from entityType to childEntityType (as it's defined in the interface apparently).

Doesn't the double for-loop now introduce the possibility that an EntityId/AggregateIdentifier annotated field, which was set through the first type of the handlerInspector.getAllHandlers().keySet() set, is overwritten by a second? Or is this dealt with through a predefined ordering in the handlerInspector.getAllHandlers()?
Or(!), am I missing something obvious? ;-p
Whoa, you're right! This is a serious issue. I'll fix it and cover it with test cases.

Then again, the issue persists with the old implementation as well: having more than one @AggregateIdentifier/@EntityId annotated fields in the same aggregate. Overriding would happen anyway.
IMO aggregate identifier should be present on top aggregate only. What should be our strategy if we find more than one aggregate identifier field in the polymorphic hierarchy?
Very good point, this was already a potential "bug". Let's discuss this further face-to-face to come to a conclusion 👍
In meeting we discussed to throw an AggregateModellingException if a second @EntityId/@AggregateVersion annotated field is noticed.
Is this TODO still present in subsequent commits? If so, think it would be best to resolve this prior to merging.
An open question.
I think it's fine to have this method in the AnnotatedHandlerInspector to be honest.
In meeting we decided against moving it to the AnnotatedHandlerInspector, hence it'll stay in here.
No description? 😢

Ain't nobody got time for that :D.
I'll add it.
Lol
Mega nit: the indentation is slightly messy in this method.
Wouldn't a Set make more sense? 🤔

Instead of:
Registers a subtype of this aggregate. Supports aggregate polymorphism.

I'd write:
Registers a subtype of this aggregate to support aggregate polymorphism.

Nit: not so much with the actual test, but more so a comment on JUnit 5 usage: you can omit public from all @Test annotated methods. Not sure why it's still there on the other test functions to be honest...
No documentation? 😢

nodes.bodyText: ambiguous description "commands of provided subtype". I suggest describing it as "Command Handlers defined on this subtype will be considered part of this aggregate's handlers."
Consider changing to public AgggregateConfigurer withSubtype(...) to allow for easier configuration.
Is this change necessary? It would be nice for the test to show API compatibility hasn't changed. The GenericAggregateFactory seems to still have the overloaded method.
I'd prefer a protected accessor method (aggregateModel()) over a protected field.
Not sure why this needs to be deprecated. It's just a quicker way of creating a factory that just creates instances of the given aggregate type, without supporting any subtypes.

nodes.bodyText:
This may cause a breaking change. Until now, the "type" of a DomainEventMessage wasn't used.
I suggest accepting unmatched types when the aggregateModel doesn't define any polymorphic types. In that case, we can silently accept "mistypes". If the model does define multiple polymorphic types, then we should throw an exception.
This is inspection at runtime. Favor inspection at startup time instead, simply calling the constructors that have been "discovered" in that phase.
Ideally, this test wouldn't require any change to pass. The aggregateType wasn't used in the past, and unless polymorphism is used, the type shouldn't really matter.
Not sure why this is required. The test seems to want to create a new book instance, which means that the Aggregate (wrapper class) should be initialized with an instance at first.
The test was wrong here. We need an actual instance (instead of null), otherwise, we cannot initialize the aggregate.

The AnnotatedAggregate class will only initialize the aggregate once. So if you initialize it with a Book instance, the test will actually have a second instance created, but that instance is then not part of the AnnotatedAggregate. It does look like all events are applied on the correct instance, but it's not really the way the AnnotatedAggregate should be used.
Instead of passing an empty Book instance, use:
AnnotatedAggregate<Book> bookAggregate = AnnotatedAggregate.initialize((Callable<Book>) () ->
                                                                                       new Book(new CreateBookCommand("book1")),
                                                                               bookAggregateModel,
                                                                               mockEventBus);
"Interesting" class name ;-)

nodes.bodyText: Looks like you're returning an empty TreeSet, but don't register that as the value of handlers (as would be the case in computeIfAbsent). If you just want to return an empty stream, it's better to use getOrDefault(type, emptySet()).
getOrDefault(type, emptySortedSet()) :)
I suggest throwing an UnsupportedOperationException instead.

nodes.bodyText:
Confusing parameter name. The type is that of the aggregate, not the event. The fact that it's the type derived from the first event, it not relevant in this scope anymore. I suggest using "aggregateType" instead.
Also, the method should allow inexistent types if no substypes are declared in the aggregate, to ensure compatibility with 4.2, where aggregate type wasn't used to initialize an aggregate.
Would be nice for the test to pass without modifications, to show backwards compatibility.

+/**

nodes.bodyText: Suggestion: why not add a constructor for the AggregateTestFixture which contains a Class<?>... parameter for the subtypes?
Class<? extends T>..., to be exact ;-)
But of course ;-p

You'd suggest having something like:
AggregateTestFixture(Class<T> aggregateType, Class<? extends T>... subtypes)

and to be used like:
fixture = new AggregateTestFixture<>(AggregateA.class, AggregateB.class, AggregateC.class);

Which I find pretty cryptic to determine what is the actual type of this aggregate. What do you think?

The first class will always be the actual aggregate type right? To be honest I think it's fine, but if you feel strongly against it, then you live it as is. You could also add a registerSubtypes(Class<? extends T>... subtypes) as a shorthand instead.
Nit: you could use the Matchers#predicate method to create the PredicateMatcher.
Don't forget the @return in the javadoc

There seem to be 2 different "levels of expectation" in the API. The model returns a Type based on the type from the event, and if that is not found, it asks for the default constructor from the AggregateModel. The latter seems a bit out of place: the Model assumes default constructors are used to instantiate empty aggregates. That assumption belongs in the GenericAggregateFactory.
I suggest something along the lines of:
newInstance(aggregateModel().type(firstEvent.getType())
                             .orElse(getAggregateType));

In that case, AggregateModel doesn't need to expose any default constructors. Just types.
I moved inspection of constructors to the model to be inline with #1317 (comment) . Where do you propose to inspect constructors?
Addressed.

Does subTypes strictly need to be a Set? The API would be friendlier is it's just a Collection or Iterable.
Or perhaps have the static method defined as:
public static <T> AggregateModel<T> inspectAggregate(Class<T> aggregateType, Class<? extends T>... subtypes) 

Inside that static method, you could add them to a set to have that set used throughout the rest of the inspector.

Not overly certain on this part, but I recall suggesting the usages of Set earlier in the PR. Reasoning behind that would've been to ensure no duplicate aggregate sub-types would be inserted. If that advantage is outweighed by using an Iterable, I'll back-off.
I have the same concern here about clarity if we choose to go for varargs.
@abuijze and I decided that approach with (Class<T>, Class<? extends T>...) looks pretty weird for usage, so we won't be pursuing it.

As stated in another comment, I don't think the model should expose constructors. It forces implementation to use default constructors, instead of allowing AggregateFactory implementations to creates instances otherwise (e.g. using prototype Spring beans)

Same as above. If an AggregateFactory assumes default constructor, the Model should expose all the types declared in this Model, and the AggregateFactory should check for the presence of default constructors, where relevant.
Default constructor knowledge in model.... see other comments.
